DataElement.preferredName: Urine Phenol and Paraben Concentration in Nanograms per Milliliter Concentration
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The fluid that is excreted by the kidneys.  It is stored in the bladder and discharged through the urethra._Hydroxybenzene; Carbolic Acid. Used as a germicidal agent and as an intermediate in chemical synthesis.  Highly toxic; corrosive to the skin._An alkyl ester of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA) that is used most often as a preservative in various personal care products. Parabens are active against a broad spectrum of microorganisms and exert their activity by disrupting the integrity of the cell membrane, causing leakage of intracellular proteins and interference with membrane transport processes, by inhibiting synthesis of DNA and RNA or by inhibiting the activity of certain enzymes, such as ATPases and phosphotransferases._The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts._A numeric represention of the concentration of a solution expressed as number of nanograms per milliliter.

Highly toxic; corrosive to the skin.:No Value Exists:The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. Concepts.definition: Hydroxybenzene; Carbolic Acid. Used as a germicidal agent and as an intermediate in chemical synthesis.  Highly toxic; corrosive to the skin.

An alkyl ester of p-hydroxybenzoic acid (PHBA) that is used most often as a preservative in various personal care products. Parabens are active against a broad spectrum of microorganisms and exert their activity by disrupting the integrity of the cell membrane, causing leakage of intracellular proteins and interference with membrane transport processes, by inhibiting synthesis of DNA and RNA or by inhibiting the activity of certain enzymes, such as ATPases and phosphotransferases.

The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Concentration in Nanograms per Milliliter Concentration
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A numeric represention of the concentration of a solution expressed as number of nanograms per milliliter.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: The quantity of a substance per unit volume or weight; a measure of the amount of substance present in a unit amount of mixture, particularly, the amount of solute dissolved in a solvent. The amounts can be expressed as moles, masses, volumes, or parts.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.

ReferenceDocuments.name: PQT
ReferenceDocuments.description: Collect and analyze a urine sample to determine the concentrations of several phenolic compounds such as bisphenol A (BPA) used to make plastic water bottles, children's toys, and baby bottles. This bioassay also describes analysis of parabens, which are chemicals used as preservatives in foods and beverages and in cosmetics and pharmaceuticals.
